DataElement.preferredName: Patient Diabetes Organ Complication Personal Medical History Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the type of complication caused by diabetes.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Diabetes Organ Complication Personal Medical History
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to report of medical events in a person where disease with inadequate control of blood sugars or insufficient production of insulin is diagnosed accompanied by other organ disease or failure.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Diabetes Mellitus Organ Complication Personal Medical History
Property.preferredDefinition: (dye-a-BEE-teez) A disease in which the body does not properly control the amount of sugar in the blood. As a result, the level of sugar in the blood is too high. This disease occurs when the body does not produce enough insulin or does not use it properly.:A part of the body that performs a specific function.  For example, the heart is an organ.:Complication; any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of (or because of) another disease.:an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A metabolic disorder characterized by abnormally high blood sugar levels due to diminished production of insulin or insulin resistance/desensitization.

A unique macroscopic (gross) anatomic structure that performs specific functions. It is composed of various tissues.  An organ is part of an anatomic system or a body region. Representative examples include the heart, lung, liver, spleen, and uterus.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredName: Chronic or Associated Diseases and Exposures
